Plenty of people will tell you itâ€™s normal to ask about what somebody does for a living, and it is common, but there are still those of us who donâ€™t like it. I do complain about work to friends who are coworkers, but complaining to outsiders doesnâ€™t help blow off so much steam.

Plenty of people consider politics off-limits. Iâ€™m a college student (commenters keep mentioning that, so maybe my opinion is less common after college?), and I really like discussing politics IF 1. itâ€™s not in a situation where someone has influence over me (e.g. at work or in front of a professor), 2. my conversation partners donâ€™t think disagreements are personal insults or signs that youâ€™re immoral, and 3. itâ€™s not the first/only thing people ask about.  I spent some time in Israel/Palestine and a few Jewish strangers would approach me and asked me for my opinion on American politics. That made me feel very uncomfortable, since I had no other interaction with them and didnâ€™t know how they would take disagreements. (I was also a relatively small person who was a stranger to the area. Large men standing in front of me to ask about anything they seemed passionate about mightâ€™ve creeped me out.) Retrospectively, I wish Iâ€™dâ€™ve discussed it with them, but at the time I felt hesitant.

I try to ask about what people have been doing lately, or theiropinions on whatever theyâ€™ve been reading. Some people donâ€™t have much to say in response, but the people Iâ€™d like to be friends with do.

The best thing is when somebody has a quirky hobby or interest and you get to learn about that from them.

Iâ€™m an American (not a farmer, though Iâ€™ve been on a family memberâ€™s farm and helped out some) and have tried horse abroad. If I had thought of the horse as a pet I would try to avoid it, but if I had seen it as a working animal Iâ€™d probably go ahead.
